repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Added some improvements to the lua meta doc gen:

* [x] fix indentation for params. This ensures param descriptions are not interpreted as a markdown code block
* [x] better support for vim code blocks
* [x] generate markdown code blocks for `vimfn`
* [x] render help tags as markdown links like `[helptag](help://helptag)` instead of just `tag`  (useful with `<gx>`)
* [x] added support for help links to `vim.ui.open()`

comment_data.body: Nit: We've recently changed the Lua doc convention to always insert a space before the `@`: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25345
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -211,6 +211,39 @@ local function get_api_meta()
   return ret
 end
 
+---@param text string

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  local help = path:match('^help://(.+)$')
  if is_uri and help then
    local ok, err = pcall(vim.cmd.help, help)
    return {
      code = ok and 0 or 1,
      stderr = not ok and err or nil,
    }
  else
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -129,7 +129,16 @@ function M.open(path)
     path = { path, 'string' },
   })

-  if not is_uri then
+  if is_uri then
+    local help = path:match('^help://(.+)$')
+    if help then
+      local ok, err = pcall(vim.cmd.help, help)
+      return {
+        code = ok and 0 or 1,
+        stderr = not ok and err or nil,
+      }
+    end
+  else

comment_data.body:
Both styles are allowed.
See the updated `dev-lua-doc`:

```
Docstring format:
- Use LuaCATS annotations: https://luals.github.io/wiki/annotations/
- Limited markdown is supported.
  - List-items start with `-` (useful to nest or "indent")
- Use ``` for code samples.
  Code samples can be annotated as `vim` or `lua`
- Use `@nodoc` to prevent documentation generation.
- Files which has `@meta` are only used for typing and documentation.
```

Please let's stop nitpicking about this in PRs. If it's important enough to have consistent it should go into a `make luaformat`

@@ -624,49 +621,50 @@ vim.bo.buflisted = vim.o.buflisted
 vim.bo.bl = vim.bo.buflisted
 
 --- The value of this option specifies the type of a buffer:
----   <empty>	normal buffer
----   acwrite	buffer will always be written with `BufWriteCmd`s
----   help		help buffer (do not set this manually)
----   nofile	buffer is not related to a file, will not be written
----   nowrite	buffer will not be written
----   quickfix	list of errors `:cwindow` or locations `:lwindow`
----   terminal	`terminal-emulator` buffer
----   prompt	buffer where only the last line can be edited, meant
---- 		to be used by a plugin, see `prompt-buffer`
+--- <empty>  normal buffer
+--- acwrite  buffer will always be written with [BufWriteCmd](help://BufWriteCmd)s
+--- help    help buffer (do not set this manually)
+--- nofile  buffer is not related to a file, will not be written
+--- nowrite  buffer will not be written
+--- quickfix  list of errors [:cwindow](help://:cwindow) or locations [:lwindow](help://:lwindow)
+--- terminal  [terminal-emulator](help://terminal-emulator) buffer
+--- prompt  buffer where only the last line can be edited, meant
+---   to be used by a plugin, see [prompt-buffer](help://prompt-buffer)

comment_regular_data.body:
> render help tags as |tag| instead of just tag

Can you explain the rationale for this? `vim_docgen` already seems to generate taglinks from the current code, and they don't look useful in hover? 

Also, shouldn't it be, e.g., |extmarks| then instead of \`|extmarks|\` (_replace_ backticks by bars)?

To make a distinction between an inline code and a tag. see:
![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/292349/f924869d-df90-43b0-a9d5-c0db8c20a69c)

Those tags can still be used with `<K>` this way.

The extra backticks are to make it not look like regular text.
Could also be made bold i that makes more sense.
Ah, I see, you want to mimic the vimdoc parser using markdown parsing. Making `<K>` work is a compelling reason, I was not aware this worked in an LSP hover.

It doesn't work yet by default I believe, since the keywordprg for markdown is probably the default man, but it's easy to set it to help for markdown.

Could also be a future improvment to the new lsp hovers that automatically map `K` for Neovim meta functions to `help` when its a help tag
So then I'm confused -- the point is just cosmetic, to mimic the corresponding help page?
It's both cosmetic (markdown is a document formatter after all) and useful if you set keyword prog to help.
I'm not sure why the backticks are necessary. Tags already have their own highlight, and `|` are supposed to be concealed.

Ok, then I missed that somehow.

Previously you removed the tags and replaced them with back ticks.

So we just should no longer do anything with help tags and leave them as is?

How do they get highlighted though? In lsp hover docs I mean?

Ah right I'm following now. I changed it because `|` tags aren't markdown so backticks were the closest analog. (Forgot the LSP descriptions are markdown).

With that said, I'm not particularly fond of this change. If we want `K` to work then we need to design a proper keywordprg and not make the text a Frankenstein of markdown and vimdoc.

What about using backticks in a markdown link? Is that something that could work?

> It's both cosmetic (markdown is a document formatter after all) and useful if you set keyword prog to help.

I'm sorry for being obtuse about this, but I still don't get it:
1. we already had cosmetic formatting (via _just_ backticks); adding bars in markdown is a pure skeuomorphism;
2. since the `keywordprg` is _not_ set to help currently, the bars don't actually do anything?

(The latter is certainly an improvement we can talk about, if that can be done reasonably easily and consistently -- the lsp hover function doesn't know anything about the contents, after all, except that they are markdown -- but personally I would make these adjustments together, instead of one now in the vague hope that it could be useful in the future?)

(Ideally, we could somehow use inline injections, but I don't see any way currently of doing that.)

ok, better idea:
- `gx` now uses `vim.ui.open()`
- We can make the helptags a real markdown link that links to `help:foo`.
- Then in `vim.ui.open` we can show help if the protocol is `help`.
Alternatively, I can make it a real link that links to the actual docs website., but that may be less useful

just adding as a reminder that lsp hover & markdown needs to work with any language server.  We should avoid server specific handling if we can avoid it. For other languages and servers `|marker|` might be plain text

For example, instead of a keywordprg/help special case we could consider regular markdown hyperlink syntax with a file uri, or maybe introduce a special `(vim-)help://` scheme.
@mfussenegger yes, that's what I was suggesting above

I echo @mfussenegger's concern about no special cookies for luals, even if that is a common dev tool for us.

I would also recommend moving the whole helptag business to a separate PR in order not to hold up the other (very welcome and uncontroversial) changes.
Changed to actual markdown links and added support for `help://` to `vim.ui.open`

You can only use `gx` on the links when `conceallevel=0` of course.

A future PR could improve url handling for markdown.

repo.name: neovim

title: docs: improvements to lua annotation generation
